dn2:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
dn2:3.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
dn2:3.7: “Mendicants, I will teach you the explanation of the restraint of all defilements.
dn2:3.8: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
dn2:4.1: “Mendicants, I say that the ending of defilements is for one who knows and sees, not for one who does not know or see.
dn2:4.2: For one who knows and sees what?
dn2:4.4: When you focus your mind irrationally, defilements arise, and once arisen they grow.
dn2:4.5: When you focus your mind rationally, defilements don’t arise, and those that have already arisen are given up.
dn2:5.1: Some defilements should be given up by seeing, some by restraint, some by using, some by enduring, some by avoiding, some by getting rid of, and some by developing.
dn2:7.1: And what are the defilements that should be given up by seeing?
dn2:7.3: Take an uneducated ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in their teaching. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in their teaching.
dn2:7.4: They don’t understand what things they should focus on and what things they shouldn’t focus on.
dn2:7.5: So they focus on things they shouldn’t focus on and don’t focus on things they should focus on.
dn2:8.1: And what are the things they shouldn’t focus on but they do?
dn2:8.2: It’s the things that, when focussed on, give rise to unarisen defilements of sensual desire,
dn2:8.4: and ignorance. And when such defilements have arisen, they make them grow.
dn2:8.5: These are the things they shouldn’t focus on but they do.
dn2:9.1: And what are the things they should focus on but they don’t?
dn2:9.2: It’s the things that, when focussed on, don’t give rise to unarisen defilements of sensual desire,
dn2:9.4: and ignorance. And when such defilements have arisen, they’re given up.
dn2:9.5: These are the things they should focus on but they don’t.
dn2:10.1: Because of focussing on what they shouldn’t and not focussing on what they should, unarisen defilements arise and arisen defilements grow.
dn2:11.1: This is how they focus irrationally.
dn2:11.3: Did I not exist in the past?
dn2:11.4: What was I in the past?
dn2:11.5: How was I in the past?
dn2:11.6: After being what, what did I become in the past?
dn2:11.7: Will I exist in the future?
dn2:11.8: Will I not exist in the future?
dn2:11.9: What will I be in the future?
dn2:11.10: How will I be in the future?
dn2:11.11: After being what, what will I become in the future?’
dn2:11.12: Or they are undecided about the present thus:
dn2:11.17: This sentient being—where did it come from?
dn2:12.1: When they focus irrationally in this way, one of six views arises in them.
dn2:12.2: The view ‘my self exists absolutely’ arises and is taken as a genuine fact.
dn2:12.3: The view ‘my self doesn’t exist absolutely’ arises and is taken as a genuine fact.
dn2:12.4: The view ‘I perceive the self with the self’ arises and is taken as a genuine fact.
dn2:12.5: The view ‘I perceive what is not-self with the self’ arises and is taken as a genuine fact.
dn2:12.6: The view ‘I perceive the self with what is not-self’ arises and is taken as a genuine fact.
dn2:12.7: Or they have such a view:
dn2:12.8: ‘This self of mine is he who speaks and feels and experiences the results of good and bad deeds in all the different realms. This self is permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable, and will last forever and ever.’
dn2:12.9: This is called a misconception, the thicket of views, the desert of views, the trick of views, the dodginess of views, the fetter of views.
dn2:12.10: An uneducated ordinary person who is fettered by views is not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
dn2:12.11: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
dn2:13.2: But take an educated noble disciple who has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in their teaching. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in their teaching.
dn2:13.3: They understand what things they should focus on and what things they shouldn’t focus on.
dn2:13.4: So they don’t focus on things they shouldn’t focus on and focus on things they should focus on.
dn2:14.1: And what are the things they shouldn’t focus on and they don’t?
dn2:14.2: It’s the things that, when focussed on, give rise to unarisen defilements of sensual desire,
dn2:14.4: and ignorance. And when such defilements have arisen, they make them grow.
dn2:14.5: These are the things they shouldn’t focus on and they don’t.
dn2:15.1: And what are the things they should focus on and they do?
dn2:15.2: It’s the things that, when focussed on, don’t give rise to unarisen defilements of sensual desire,
dn2:15.4: and ignorance. And when such defilements have arisen, they’re given up.
dn2:15.5: These are the things they should focus on and they do.
dn2:16.1: Because of not focussing on what they shouldn’t and focussing on what they should, unarisen defilements don’t arise and arisen defilements are given up.
dn2:17.1: They rationally focus: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
dn2:17.2: And as they do so, they give up three fetters:
dn2:17.3: identity view, doubt, and attachment to precepts and observances.
dn2:17.4: These are called the defilements that should be given up by seeing.
dn2:18.1: 2. The defilements given up by restraint
dn2:19.1: And what are the defilements that should be given up by restraint?
dn2:19.2: Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, lives restraining the eye faculty.
dn2:19.3: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without restraint of the eye faculty do not arise when there is such restraint.
dn2:19.4: Reflecting rationally, they live restraining the faculty of the ear …
dn2:19.13: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without restraint of the mind faculty do not arise when there is such restraint.
dn2:20.1: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without restraint do not arise when there is such restraint.
dn2:20.2: These are called the defilements that should be given up by restraint.
dn2:22.1: And what are the defilements that should be given up by using?
dn2:22.2: Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, makes use of robes:
dn2:22.3: ‘Only for the sake of warding off cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; for warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; and to shelter from harsh weather and enjoy retreat.’
dn2:23.1: Reflecting rationally, they make use of almsfood:
dn2:23.2: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to continue and sustain this body, avoid harm, and support spiritual practice. So that I will put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and so that I will keep on living blamelessly and at ease.’
dn2:24.1: Reflecting rationally, they make use of lodgings:
dn2:24.2: ‘Only for the sake of warding off cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; for warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; and to shelter from harsh weather and enjoy retreat.’
dn2:25.1: Reflecting rationally, they make use of medicines and supplies for the sick:
dn2:25.2: ‘Only for the sake of warding off the pains of illness and to promote good health.’
dn2:26.1: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without using these things do not arise when they are used.
dn2:26.2: These are called the defilements that should be given up by using.
dn2:28.1: And what are the defilements that should be given up by using?
dn2:28.2: Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst. They endure the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles. They endure rude and unwelcome criticism. And they put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
dn2:29.1: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without enduring these things do not arise when they are endured.
dn2:29.2: These are called the defilements that should be given up by enduring.
dn2:31.1: And what are the defilements that should be given up by avoiding?
dn2:31.2: Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, avoids a wild elephant, a wild horse, a wild ox, a wild dog, a snake, a stump, thorny ground, a pit, a cliff, a swamp, and a sewer.
dn2:31.3: Rationally reflecting, they avoid sitting on inappropriate seats, walking in inappropriate neighborhoods, and mixing with bad friends—whatever sensible spiritual companions would believe to be a bad setting.
dn2:32.1: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without avoiding these things do not arise when they are avoided.
dn2:32.2: These are called the defilements that should be given up by avoiding.
dn2:33.1: 6 Defilements given up by getting rid
dn2:34.1: And what are the defilements that should be given up by getting rid?
dn2:34.2: Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that’s arisen, but gives it up, gets rid of it, eliminates it, and exterminates it.
dn2:34.6: They don’t tolerate any bad, unwholesome qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and exterminate them.
dn2:35.1: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without getting rid of these things do not arise when they are gotten rid of.
dn2:35.2: These are called the defilements that should be given up by getting rid.
dn2:37.1: And what are the defilements that should be given up by development?
dn2:37.2: Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, develops the awakening-factors of mindfulness,
dn2:37.9: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.
dn2:38.1: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without developing these things do not arise when they are developed.
dn2:38.2: These are called the defilements that should be given up by developing.
dn2:39.1: Now, take a mendicant who, by restraint, has given up the defilements that should be given up by restraint. By using, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by using. By enduring, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by enduring. By avoiding, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by avoiding. By enduring, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by enduring. By dispelling, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by dispelling.
dn2:39.3: They’re called a mendicant who lives having restrained all defilements, who has cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.”
dn2:40.1: This is what the Buddha said.
dn2:40.2: Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
